headline: Fall Forecast: Cool and Tasty
summary: Each season, color authority Pantone polls designers and reviews orders for its own color swatches to forecast what will be the most popular colors for men and women. Here they are for Fall 2012.

headline: Franchisees Versus Franchiser
summary: An association of Cold Stone Creamery Inc. franchisees filed this complaint in a Florida state court last month against the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based chain.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Bankruptcy and Back
summary: See highlights from the history of Barneys.

headline: Calix, Guidance Software: Biggest Price Gainers (CALX, GUID)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Giant View of Super Bowl Parade
summary: See a 360-degree view from 61 Broadway in Lower Manhattan as fans cheered the New York Giants' Super Bowl win.

headline: The Richest of the Rich
summary: The college-basketball teams whose alumni have earned the most money in the NBA, starting with players who entered the league in 1985.

headline: Company Earnings in Europe and at Home
summary: Compare the total revenue with revenue generated in Europe in the fourth quarter for 39 companies with significant sales in Europe, and the change in revenues.

headline: CD Yields Remain Flat
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were mostly unchanged in the latest week.

headline: Lenovo Net Profit Surges 54%
summary: Chinese computer maker Lenovo Group said its third-quarter net profit rose 54% from a year earlier, but warned that it expects a global hard disk drive shortage to continue into the next quarter, potentially impacting its margins.

headline: U.S. to Sue Banks Over Bonds
summary: Federal securities regulators plan to warn several major banks that they intend to sue them over mortgage-related actions linked to the financial crisis.

headline: Illumina Assessed ConflictsBefore Hiring Goldman
summary: A biotechnology company that retainedInc. for advice in fending off a hostile suitor revealed that it assessed conflict-of-interest concerns before hiring the bank.

headline: One News Corp. Hack Case Set to Go to Trial
summary: News Corp.'s U.K. tabloid-newspaper unit has settled 54 of the 60 civil phone-hacking claims that victims had filed. A suit by singer Charlotte Church is the only one set to go to trial.

headline: Sarkozy Ally Under Investigation
summary: Nicolas Sarkozy's former fund-raiser, Eric Woerth, was put under formal investigation for alleged influence peddling in a case that could embarrass the French head of state three months ahead of the presidential election.

headline: U.S. Officials Lower Jobless Forecast
summary: The recent spate of good economic news has led White House officials to lower their projections for the unemployment rate this year, with a top adviser saying the 8.9% estimate that will appear in the White House's budget proposal Feb. 13 is already "stale and out of date."

headline: Telstra Posts 23% Profit Rise
summary: Australia's largest telecommunications company, Telstra, said first-half profit rose 23% as it continued to attract more customers and make cost savings.

headline: Knicks Live Without Stars
summary: Jeremy Lin and others have stepped up to fill the void with Carmelo Anthony and Amar'e Stoudemire out

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: An actor performs a traditional dance in east China, college students shout slogans at a job hunting ceremony in Tokyo, rescuers search for missing people after an earthquake in the Philippines and more.

headline: U.N. Investigative Body to Stay in Guatemala
summary: A special United Nations investigative unit said Wednesday it would remain in Guatemala for at least another three years, continuing what many experts say is a successful experiment in prosecuting crime in the Latin American drug wars.

headline: Washington State Lawmakers Pass Gay-Marriage Bill
summary: Washington State lawmakers voted to approve gay marriage, setting the stage for the state to become the seventh in the nation to allow same-sex couples to wed.

headline: Chinese Fund to Back Films in U.S., China
summary: A government-backed Chinese film fund said it will begin co-financing and co-producing movies in both China and the U.S.

headline: MacMillan Resigns as Stryker Chairman, CEO
summary: Stryker said Stephen P. MacMillan resigned as the company's chairman, president and chief executive for family reasons, effective immediately.

headline: Dodd-Frank Omission Sparks Dispute
summary: An oversight in drafting the financial-overhaul law threatens to undermine a potent tool for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and has caused banks to resist turning over certain documents.

headline: Investor Views of Euro Zone Brighten
summary: The hopes for a successful conclusion to the latest Greek debt talks take financial markets closer to having the sword of Damocles removed from over investors' heads.

headline: Investors Put Cash in Mutual Funds
summary: Long-term mutual funds had estimated net inflows of $8 billion in the latest week, as investors continued to add money to bonds and hybrid funds, offsetting withdrawals from equities, according to the Investment Company Institute.

headline: Rove: Newt's Southern Strategy Won't Work
summary: Santorum's Tuesday wins make him, for now at least, Romney's main conservative challenger.

headline: Hostess Seeks Lucrative Deal for CEO
summary: Hostess Brands Inc. is seeking court permission for a new employment deal that would hand millions of dollars to Chief Executive Brian J. Driscoll, "architect" of the company's plan to cut costs and jettison its pension plans.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Robert Nozick on the strong self-regard of intellectuals.

headline: Virginia Lacrosse Player's Murder Trial Begins

headline: Eswar Prasad: Will China's Yuan Rival the Dollar?
summary: Safe and liquid financial markets help make for a strong currency. Beijing isn't there yet.

headline: Audit Watchdog Fines Ernst & Young $2 Million
summary: Ernst & Young agreed to pay $2 million to settle allegations by the government's auditing regulator that the firm wasn't skeptical enough in assessing how a client, Medicis Pharmaceutical, accounted for a reserve covering product returns.

headline: Argentina's YPF Boosts Shale-Oil Estimate
summary: Argentina's YPF sharply raised its estimate for its unconventional oil-and-gas resources to 22.8 billion barrels from 927 million barrels.

headline: Banks Lift Stocks
summary: Stocks drifted a smidgeon higher, as investors awaited an agreement among Greek politicians on reforms ahead of the country's second international bailout.

headline: CME Nears Deal to Sell CBOT Site
summary: CME Group is close to a deal to sell most of the historic Chicago Board of Trade building for between $150 million and $180 million.

summary: Pennsylvania lawmakers passed a bill to rewrite state laws governing natural-gas drilling, capping a multiyear debate within the state about how to responsibly drill for natural gas in the Marcellus Shale formation.

headline: New York Tells Citi, Assurant to Cooperate
summary: Probe explores whether banks and insurers charged exorbitant fees to homeowners who let their insurance policies lapse.

headline: Goldman Snags Old AIG Bonds
summary: Goldman Sachs Group won a hotly contested auction for a large bundle of risky mortgage bonds from the 2008 bailout of American International Group, in a sale that was a victory for both the Wall Street firm and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Toyota to Shift Highlander Hybrid Production to U.S.
summary: Toyota will invest $400 million in its Indiana plant as it shifts production of the Highlander sport-utility vehicle hybrid to the U.S. from Japan.

headline: Visa Profit Rises as Card Use Jumps
summary: Visa posted a 16% increase in fiscal first-quarter profit as the credit-card processor continued to benefit from consumers' increased use of plastic.

headline: Jenkins: Revisiting the Auto Bailout With Clint
summary: Detroit is hostage to the administration's green energy schemes—a perfect vehicle for granting favors and extorting tribute.

headline: Nissan Gains a Step on Japanese Rivals
summary: Nissan posted a higher quartelry profit and reaffirmed its full-year estimate, positioning itself as the most profitable of Japan's three major auto makers.

headline: Buyers Drive IPO Price Cuts
summary: A slate of IPOs met with success after most lowered their asking prices, an indication that buyers are driving a hard bargain when it comes to getting deals done.

summary: The euro was little changed, oscillating just below an eight-week high as markets awaited news on Greece's efforts to forge political consensus on a debt and bailout agreement needed to avert default.

headline: Treasurys Stall After 10-Year Sale
summary: Treasurys ended pretty much right where they started after getting battered around by a stream of Greece reports, talk of U.S. monetary stimulus and a less-than-inspiring bond auction.

headline: MBIA Acknowledges Errors in Making Case to Split
summary: MBIA has acknowledged making errors when predicting future losses before the mortgage-bond insurer received approval from regulators to split three years ago, but says the errors wouldn't have changed the decision. Some policyholders disagree.

headline: Crude Tacks on Small Gains
summary: Crude-oil futures finished slightly higher after a government report showed U.S. crude-oil stockpiles rose less than expected last week, although oil demand overall was weak.

headline: U.K. Fires Back Over Falkland Islands
summary: The Falkland Islands are British because they choose to be and there will be no negotiations with Argentina over their sovereignty unless the islanders wish it, the U.K. government said.

headline: Reckitt to Realign for Growth
summary: Reckitt Benckiser said it is shifting its focus to booming emerging markets as the consumer-goods and health-care giant posted a 26% jump in fourth-quarter earnings.

summary: Telenor should be cashing in on its successes, but an unhealthy attachment to India and Russia is holding it back.

headline: Xstrata Shouldn't Fear Glencore Divorce
summary: CEOs Mick Davis and Ivan Glasenberg would like the world to believe their proposed merger of Xstrata and Glencore is a marriage made in heaven. But to some investors, it may seem more like a shotgun wedding.

headline: RBS Chief Pondered Resignation
summary: The chief executive of embattled Royal Bank of Scotland mounted a media blitz in hopes of moving the bank past a bruising public battle over his bonus that he said left him contemplating resignation.

summary: Sanofi warned earnings would fall in 2012 as the French drug maker loses patent protection in the U.S. on some of its blockbuster drugs.

headline: Fed Postpones Capital One Ruling
summary: The Federal Reserve is delaying a planned meeting on Capital One's bid to buy ING Direct USA, rescheduling it to Monday.

summary: Sprint Nextel posted a wider loss, though subscriber growth helped boost the wireless carrier's revenue.

headline: Qantas Finds Wing Cracks  in A380

summary: Rambus signed a five-year licensing agreement with Nvidia as the chip companies settled all of their outstanding patent disputes.

headline: Higher One Holdings, Silicon Graphics International: Biggest Price Decliners (ONE, SGI)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: ICE Sees Strong Revenue Growth in 2012
summary: IntercontinentalExchange executives said they expect 2012 revenue to grow by at least 10%. The derivatives exchange operator reported a 28% gain in quarterly profit.

summary: Renesas Electronics, Fujitsu and Panasonic are in talks to integrate some specialized chip operations in an effort to turn around their businesses and focus on more competitive chips.

summary: CVS Caremark's fourth-quarter profit rose 3.7% as pharmacy-services and retail revenue grew.

headline: Alcoa Reviews Australia Smelter
summary: Alcoa put an Australian smelter under review, joining the ranks of companies casting doubt on manufacturing in parts of Australia.

headline: Concession Smooths Way Toward a Greek Deal
summary: The ECB made key concessions over its holdings of Greek bonds, which will contribute to a reduction of the country's debt burden and smooth the path toward a new bailout.

summary: Reynolds American said fourth-quarter earnings rose 16% as higher prices and productivity improvements helped lift operating margins, offsetting a decline in cigarette volume.

headline: Aussie Aluminum Heading for Scrap Heap
summary: Low metals prices, high costs and the strong Australian dollar are doing to the country's aluminum-smelting industry what a frat boy does to his empty beer can: crushing it.

headline: Turkey Wants Syria Pressure Group

headline: Hedge Funds Added Small Gains in January
summary: Hedge-fund performance perked up in January, although the sector continued to lag the major stock indexes.

summary: China greatly increased its presence in the Japanese debt market last year, a move likely to give ammunition to those calling on Beijing to open up its own financial markets to outside investors.

headline: W.R. Grace Splits Unit Into Two

headline: Ralph Lauren Forecasts Strong Sales
summary: Ralph Lauren Corp. reported flat earnings as higher taxes and costs damped better-than-expected revenue growth. But investors were cheered by a forecast for continuing strong sales.

headline: Citi Names New Senior Asia-Pacific Team

headline: Star Power?

headline: ONGC Profit Falls 5%

headline: Jones Group Posts Smaller Loss
summary: Jones Group reported a narrower fourth-quarter loss as materials costs showed a decline. Revenue rose, but was held back by promotional activity.

headline: German Costs Stay Low

headline: Telenor Chief: Limit India License Rerun

headline: China Pushes Yuan in Latin America
summary: Chinese policy banks are seeking to expand lending to commodities-rich countries in Latin America using the yuan instead of the dollar.

headline: Bahrain's Batelco to Exit India

headline: Hard Times for U.K. Landlords
summary: If the U.K. economic downturn is causing misery for retailers, spare a thought for their landlords. In many towns outside London, one in four shops is vacant; that's a higher vacancy rate than Athens.

headline: Moody's Profit Falls 30%; Outlook Upbeat
summary: The ratings and analytics company's expenses in the fourth quarter again overpowered solid revenue.

headline: Santorum Sweeps Three States
summary: Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum won the Minnesota and Colorado caucuses and a primary in Missouri on Tuesday.

headline: Uttar Pradesh Polls Begin
summary: The first phase of the Uttar Pradesh assembly elections began Wednesday. Some snapshots.

headline: Education on a Roadside
summary: A man in the western Indian city of Ahmedabad has launched a unique initiative to help educate underprivileged children. Some snapshots.

headline: Tibetans Burning
summary: Beijing blames the Dalai Lama, but suicides show his influence is waning.

headline: Bharti Airtel Profit Drops 22%

headline: TiVo Demand Boosts Virgin Media
summary: Virgin Media posted solid fourth-quarter results, including a 30% jump in net profit, driven by a strong consumer appetite for its new pay-television service and for superfast broadband.

headline: India Shares End Higher
summary: Indian shares closed higher Wednesday, with gains in some index heavyweights and regional markets helping more than offset sharp losses in Bharti Airtel.

headline: S&P Cuts Sony Rating, Warns of Further Action
summary: S&P lowered its long-term debt ratings on Sony to two notches above junk status and gave the Japanese electronics company a negative outlook.

headline: Lenovo Says Lanci Didn't Violate Acer Deal
summary: Lenovo said it is confident that its relationship with Acer's former CEO meets all legal requirements, after the rival computer maker started legal action against him for breaching a noncompete clause in a contract.

headline: India Minister: Tough To Implement Food Security Law
summary: India's plan to roll out an ambitious food security program won't succeed unless the government revamps a creaky distribution network and boosts other infrastructure, the Farm Minister said.

headline: Thomas Cook Mulls India Stake Sale
summary: Thomas Cook said it will consider selling its Indian foreign exchange and travel business as the U.K. tour operator reported a first-quarter loss.

headline: Facing Criticism, China Hints at Syria Action
summary: China said it is considering dispatching envoys to Syria after Beijing blocked a resolution that targeted the Syrian government.

headline: UMC Profit Slumps 82%
summary: Taiwan-based UMC, the world's second-largest contract chip manufacturer, said it plans to increase 2012 capital spending by 20% after it posted an 82% fall in fourth-quarter net profit.

summary: Car sales in India gained for the third consecutive month in January but the recovery came late as the local body of auto makers expects car sales to miss its guidance of up to 2% growth in the current financial year through March.

headline: Statoil Earmarks $17B For Exploration, Development
summary: Statoil says it expects to spend $17 billion this year to develop its existing resources and a similar level of exploration activity as last year as it posts a sharp rise in fourth-quarter earnings due to reduced losses on net financial items.

headline: Blue Chips Hit a Yearly High
summary: Blue chips closed at a fresh multiyear high as investors saw progress in Greece over austerity measures to address its debt crisis.

headline: Reliance in Talks With Airlines for Fuel Services
summary: Reliance Industries said it is in talks with private-sector carriers Jet Airways and Kingfisher Airlines as well as state-run Air India to provide jet fuel handling services at airports across the country.

headline: NHB to Start Mortgage Guarantee Firm in India
summary: The National Housing Bank, a unit of the Indian central bank that funds mortgage lenders, plans to start the nation's first mortgage guarantee company next fiscal year.

headline: Japan's Current Account Surplus Plunges
summary: Japan's current-account surplus shrank at its fastest rate on record in 2011, as exports stumbled and energy prices soared.

headline: A View From One Colorado County
summary: On a night when Mitt Romney faced setbacks in Missouri and Minnesota, he was the favorite in one Colorado county, just as he was in 2008.

headline: Fun With Studying
summary: The iBooks 2 app offers educational textbooks on the iPad that are, for now, focused on high-school students, writes Katherine Boehret.

headline: Mediterranean Style in Greenwich
summary: Near downtown Greenwich, Conn., this waterfront home with a large interior patio was inspired by the owner's European upbringing. Floor-to-ceiling windows show off views of the Long Island Sound.

headline: Look Who's Now Talking About Inflated College Costs
summary: Fay Vincent overlooks the argument that the federal government has a legitimate interest in seeing that public funding doesn't go into a nationwide enterprise whose double-digit annual price hikes have consistently outpaced inflation by a large margin ("Price Controls For Harvard?," op-ed, Feb. 1).

headline: Parents Helping Parents
summary: For many New York families, child rearing has nothing to do with preschool admissions madness and $1,000 designer strollers. At a gala for Room to Grow, an organization that equips needy parents with children's items and support, guests attested to just how hard it is to raise kids.

headline: UBS Will Slice 60% From Bonuses
summary: UBS said it will slash its investment-bank bonuses for 2011 by 60%, while the head of the unit will forgo any bonus following a trading scandal in September that cost the bank $2.3 billion.

headline: Prosecutors Were Split Over Armstrong
summary: The U.S. attorney who closed a nearly two-year investigation into the racing team of seven-time Tour de France champion Lance Armstrong rejected a recommendation that he pursue criminal charges in the case.

headline: Cambodia's Developers Aim at Stars
summary: A high-rise building boom in Cambodia's capital city, Phnom Penh, derailed by the 2008-2009 financial crisis, is starting up again.

headline: California Gay-Marriage Ban Rejected
summary: A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled that California's voter-mandated ban on gay marriages was unconstitutional.

headline: The Pop Scene: Welcome Back to the Jungle
summary: This week's pop calendar leads off with Guns N' Roses at several Manhattan venues, plus Bill Callahan at Lincoln Center, DJ Harvey at Santos Party House, and Die Antwoord at Irving Plaza.

headline: State Wants Sandusky Kept Home
summary: The Pennsylvania attorney general asked a judge to require that Jerry Sandusky remain inside his home as the former Pennsylvania State University football coach awaits trial on child sex abuse charges.

headline: This Is Your Life: A Musical Version
summary: During the premiere of "Smash" on Monday night (which garnered pretty solid ratings), the Drama League was hosting its own real-life version by way of its annual benefit gala.

headline: France Posts Record Trade Deficit
summary: France's trade deficit reached an all-time record last year, underscoring the loss of competitiveness of the country's national production.

headline: A Steel Site Is Recycled
summary: More than 10 years after the last steelmaking operations were closed down at the Bethlehem Steel Corp. plant in Pennsylvania, its 1,800-acre site is slowly attracting new businesses.

headline: A Prius in the Cold
summary: Jonathan Welsh answers a reader's question on why a Prius's fuel economy slips when outside temperatures are low.

headline: Inside 4 World Trade Center
summary: One World Trade Center garners all the attention, but there's another skyscraper rising on the same 16-acre site. Four World Trade Center is also going up, although not quite as high. --02/08/12

headline: Phoenix Suns Embrace On-Court Technology
summary: Don't be surprised to see Phoenix Suns head coach Alvin Gentry passing a tablet computer around the huddle during a timeout this season. Plus, Memphis is expected to join the Big East and Manny Pacquiao's next opponent.

headline: Pyramid Cos.' Carousel Plan Rides Again
summary: Developer Robert Congel's drive to create one of the largest malls in the country, in Syracuse, N.Y., is back in gear after almost being upended by the economic downturn and a nasty court battle with Citigroup.

headline: In Syria, Russia Extracts No Vows
summary: Russia held talks with Assad in Damascus that showed no sign of slowing the country's bloody conflict, as Syrian forces continued to pound the city of Homs.

headline: Arcelor Sees Tentative Recovery
summary: ArcelorMittal said it expects steel shipments to remain flat in the first half but that mining production will increase 10% as the company expands in the natural-resources sector.

headline: Japan Confirms 'Stealth' Yen Intervention
summary: Japan continued to conduct "stealth" interventions in the currency market after its highly publicized yen-selling campaign on Oct. 31, data released by the Finance Ministry confirmed.

headline: 'Junk' Bonds Still Offer Error Margin
summary: U.S. high-yield bonds still remains attractive for investors that can stomach the market's skittishness.

headline: Not Enough Transformation
summary: Obama diagnoses his political trials.

headline: You Shouldn't Need a Degree in College Aid to Get Some
summary: What a shame that the key points of financial aid are teaching families to manipulate income and savings in order provide higher education to their children ("The College-Aid Shuffle," Personal Journal, Jan. 21). I guess these same key points taught people how to apply for mortgages too.

headline: A Declaration of Lin Dependence
summary: The Harvard graduate has seized an opportunity—and the spotlight—by scoring efficiently and filling a glaring hole at point guard for the Knicks.

headline: Don't Worry, There Are Only 1,575 Steps Left
summary: Wednesday night, a record field of 650 will compete in the Empire State Building Run-Up—one of the city's quintessential events.

headline: Say 'Yes' to the Sleepover
summary: There is a rich vein of sleepover folklore, and it seems every parent has a nightmare story to share. But some are mounting a defense of the sleepover, if done right.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Feb. 8, 2012

headline: Nymex Crude's Gains Trim the Brent Premium
summary: Crude-oil futures prices settled higher after a volatile session in which global benchmarks shifted from their recent trajectories.

headline: The Quest for Cheaper, Better Lights
summary: Soraa plans to disclose the benefits of an unusual technology for manufacturing LEDs, which have found applications in areas such as traffic signals but aren't widely used to light up homes or offices.

headline: Toyota Talks Up Despite Down Quarter
summary: Toyota lifted its full-year net income forecast, but expects its earnings to come in at nearly half the level of last year, and below the profitability projections of its smaller Japanese rivals.

headline: Know Your Candidate Is Still the Best Policy
summary: Forget about using software programs ("Your Resume vs. Oblivion," Careers, Jan. 24). I'd love to see what software would do with the resume of a young Steve Jobs, Sam Zell or Warren Buffett.

headline: Kelly's Son Won't Face Charges
summary: The Manhattan district attorney's office won't charge the TV anchor son of New York City's police commissioner with rape.

headline: Above the Confetti: Giants Fans With Views
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Giants fans turned out Tuesday for the team's ticker-tape parade. But far above Broadway, office workers and high-rise residents enjoyed sweeping vistas of the confetti-strewn celebration.

headline: New Egypt Seen as More Distrustful
summary: After last year's popular revolt in Egypt, U.S. democracy-building groups thought they would gain acceptance from a government that had long viewed them with suspicion. Now election experts are looking at a different reality.

headline: MetLife Gets Baptized Blue
summary: The name of the place can't be changed to Giants Stadium, like the old venue, Justin Tuck said, "but the one thing you can be sure of is whose house this is."

headline: Switzerland Knows Just How Well Public Investment Banks Work
summary: Jean-Pierre Regli responds to Nicolas Lecaussin's "Nicolas Hollande" (op-ed, Jan. 31).

headline: Disney Profit Rises 12%
summary: Disney's fiscal first-quarter profit climbed as its ESPN network collected higher rates from cable-system operators and theme-park attendance and prices increased.
